ECHO(1) General Commands Manual ECHO(1)

NAME

echo — write arguments to standard output

SYNOPSIS

echo [-enE] [string ...]

DESCRIPTION

The echo utility writes its arguments to standard output, separated by spaces and terminated with a newline.

The options are as follows:

-e
Enable interpretation of backslash escapes.
-E
Disable interpretation of backslash escapes (default).
-n
Do not print the trailing newline character.

If -e is in effect, the following sequences are recognized:

\a
Alert (bell)
\b
Backspace
\c
Suppress further output
\e
Escape character
\f
Form feed
\n
New line
\r
Carriage return
\t
Horizontal tab
\v
Vertical tab
\\
Backslash
\0nnn
Character with octal value nnn (1-3 digits)
\xhh
Character with hex value hh (2 digits)

EXAMPLES

Print a simple message:

$ echo Hello world
Hello world

Print without newline:

$ echo -n prompt:
prompt:$

Print multiple arguments:

$ echo one two three
one two three

Print with escape sequences:

$ echo -e "Line 1\nLine 2\tTabbed"
Line 1
Line 2	Tabbed

EXIT STATUS

The echo utility exits 0 on success, and >0 if an error occurs.

SEE ALSO

printf(1)

STANDARDS

The echo utility is compliant with the IEEE Std 1003.1-2008 (“POSIX.1”) specification.

August 2, 2025 macOS 15.6
